Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(2) Summary

One of the superpowers of APIs is to design them as products with a focus on making them reusable. That helps with innovation and reuse, as teams can now consume the capabilities of other teams without having to coordinate with them, leading to faster flow. For this to work well, API versioning must be handled in a way that allows the API to evolve while at the same time not breaking existing consumers. What do you have to version? Why does it matter? When should you version? We present tips that help to improve your API design, description and documentation practices.

(4) Systems vs. Ecosystems

  • Software engineering today oftentimes includes using external components
  • Building systems implies control over the interconnected components
    • Change radius is the entire system and changes can be coordinated
  • Building ecosystems implies that control is decentralized and uncoordinated
    • Change radius are components and changes must be absorbed by the design


Why Versioning? Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(5) Programming-in-the-Huge

Source: Frank DeRemer and Hans Kron, "Programming-in-the-Large versus Programming-in-the-Small", ACM SIGPLAN Notices, Volume 10, Issue 6, Pages 114-121, April 1975



Why Versioning? Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(6) APIs as Component Interfaces

  • Private APIs are used within organizations
    • Some APIs may be internal to building systems
    • Organizations as a whole are ecosystems of various individual systems
  • Partner APIs
    • Established and managed relationships but local autonomy
  • Public APIs
    • Large-scale relationships with little mutual coordination


What to do for Versioning?

What to do for Versioning? Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(8) Loose Coupling

  • Coupling always is a trade-off
  • Tight coupling allows for runtime optimizations
  • Loose coupling makes it easier to change things at a local level
  • Decentralized scenarios are a good candidate for loose coupling
  • Changing things without breaking things is what we're all after


What to do for Versioning? Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(9) Backward and Forward Compatibility



What to do for Versioning? Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(10) Backward Compatibility

Backward compatibility is a property of a [...] technology that allows for interoperability with an older legacy system, or with input designed for such a system. (Wikipedia [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backward_compatibility])
Backward compatibility is a property of an API consumer that allows for interoperability with an older API version. (Wikipedia [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backward_compatibility])


What to do for Versioning? Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(11) Forward Compatibility

Forward compatibility [...] is a design characteristic that allows a system to accept input intended for a later version of itself. [...] A standard supports forward compatibility if a product that complies with earlier versions can gracefully process input designed for later versions of the standard, ignoring new parts which it does not understand. (Wikipedia [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_compatibility])
Forward compatibility allows a system to process data intended for a later version of itself. An API supports forward compatibility if a consumer that complies with earlier versions can gracefully process data designed for later versions of the API. (Wikipedia [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_compatibility])


What to do for Versioning? Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(12) Don't Don't Version

  • Never changing anything is not a great product management attitude
  • Changes ideally are non-breaking but still are relevant to consumers
  • Give consumers as much freedom as possible to ignore changes
  • Give consumers clear avenues to see and explore changes


What to do for Versioning? Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(13) Hyrum's Law: Every Change is a Breaking Change

(24) Identity Matters

  • URIs are about resource identity
    • Representations are handled through HTTP and media types
  • Various choices when it comes to versioned names
    • DNS: https://v1.api.example.com/
    • URI root: https://api.example.com/v1/
    • Query parameter: https://api.example.com/?version=1.0
    • HTTP header field: https://api.example.com/
